abstractText: We construct the integral transform passing from the space representation to the radial momentum representation for the Hydrogen atom. The resulting wave functions are explicitly given in terms of complex finite expansions of Gegenbauer functions of the first and second kind, or in terms of (elementary) trigonometric functions. We show their symmetry under the SO(4) group, and their equivalence with those of Lombardi and Ogilvie in [7].

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The aim of this paper is to study the construction of the wave functions of the Hydrogen atom in the momentum representation, a topic which has been considered in [1]- [7], among others. To understand why this is a non-trivial exercise in basic quantum mechanics, we need to recall some physical and mathematical ideas that will be important in the following sections. However, as we are mainly focused on physical applications, we only sketch the mathematical details.
In the canonical quantization procedure pioneered by Dirac, one starts with a
classical Hamiltonian system which, for simplicity, we will assume to be n−dimensional and having a phase space equal to R2n (that is, we avoid constraints). More generally, we could think of a 2n−dimensional cotangent manifold T ∗M , where M is a configuration space. In any case, the phase space is endowed with a canonical symplectic form w which allows the definition of things such as Hamiltonian vector fields Xf associated to classical observables f ∈ C∞(T ∗M) (that vector field is uniquely defined by the condition w(Xf , ·) = −df , where d is the exterior differential), and

the Poisson bracket of two classical observables f, g ∈ C∞(T ∗M) (defined as {f, g} = w(Xf , Xg)). Those systems admit a privileged system of so-called Darboux coordinates (q,p) = (q1, · · · , qn, p1, · · · , pn), in which the symplectic form becomes w = dqi ∧ dpi, equivalently, the Poisson brackets between the coordinates (considered as functions on the phase space) are the canonical ones: {qj, pk} = δjk. Quantization is achieved by replacing the classical observables f ∈ C∞(T ∗M) by self-adjoint operators f̂ defined on some dense subspace of the Hilbert space of squareintegrable functions L2(M, dµ), with respect to some measure dµ (to be constructed in the process), and the Poisson bracket by i~ times the commutator between operators, [f̂ , ĝ] = f̂ ◦ ĝ− ĝ◦ f̂ . Thus, the Poisson bracket of the Darboux coordinates now becomes the well-known Heisenberg canonical commutation relation
[q̂j, p̂k] = i~δjkI , (1)
where I stands for the identity operator. Notice that this relation has to be valid only in the common domain where it makes sense, and this could be the empty set [8].
Now, one can pose the question of what operators could be those q̂j, p̂k. Any
textbook on quantum mechanics presents an heuristic argument leading to the consideration of the multiplication operator
q̂jψ(q) = qjψ(q) , (2)
and the differentiation operator
p̂kψ(q) = −i~ ∂ψ(q)
∂qk . (3)
That correspondence works well when the classical configurations space is M = Rn, so the Darboux coordinates are the Cartesian ones on T ∗M = R2n, and the corresponding Hilbert space is L2(Rn, dnx), the space of square-integrable functions with respect to the Euclidean measure. In that case, both q̂j and p̂k are well-defined operators on the domain consisting, for instance, of Schwartz-class functions S(Rn), and admit unique self-adjoint extensions (with which they are identified, respectively). The uniqueness of the representation (2) and (3) is then guaranteed by the Stone-Von Neumann theorem: any other pair of operators satisfying (1), are unitarily equivalent to (2), (3).
However, it is important to understand that things are drastically different if the
configuration space is not all of Rn, or even if this is the case but we choose coordinates different from the canonical Darboux (Cartesian) ones [9]. This remark will be crucial later on.
A fundamental result in the theory of Hilbert spaces is the spectral theorem for
self-adjoint operators, which basically states that given one of these, we can find a unitary equivalence in the Hilbert space such that the transformed operator acts as a multiplication operator, that is, the transformed operator is “diagonal”. Each choice of an operator and the associated equivalence that diagonalizes it, is called a
representation of the system. In the light of this result, we can say that the canonical Dirac correspondence (2), (3) determines the position representation, as the operators q̂j are multiplication operators. Of course, we could ask what is the momentum representation, that is: What is the unitary equivalence F : L2(R, dx) → L2(R, dx) such that given the operator p̂ = −i~d/dx, the transformed operator F ◦ p̂ ◦ F−1 acts via the multiplication by identity? (We are considering the one-dimensional case for ease of notation). The answer is, of course, that F is the well-known Fourier transform, defined as
F(ψ)(p) = ∫ R e−i p·x ~ ψ(x) dx . (4)
It suffices to note that the desired result is equivalent to
F(p̂ψ)(p) = p · (Fψ)(p) . (5)
This is proved by observing that unitary operators preserve the density of the domain and the closures, and integrating by parts (since the functions ψ(x) in the domain of p̂, vanish at infinity).
Expression (5) suggests the following heuristic motivation for the introduction of
the Fourier transform: If we think of it as an integral transform whose kernel are the “eigenfunctions” of the momentum operator‡ (3), the plane waves e−i p·x~ , then it is clear that the derivative inside the integral transform, after integration by parts so that it acts on the exponential, will give us the multiplying p. Then, given that the integration is done with respect to the x variable, p can be factored outside the integral. We will generalize this idea in later sections.
Finally, after these admittedly long preliminaries, we can formulate the problem we
are interested in, which is to compute the radial wave functions (using polar spherical coordinates) of the Hydrogen atom in the momentum representation. In Section 2 we will recall the correct form of the radial momentum in these coordinates, and we will compute the unitary transformation which diagonalizes it, by means of an integral transform whose kernel is given by its formal eigenfunctions. In Section 3 we briefly review the existing literature on this subject; in particular we review the LombardiOgilvie approach, whose output is a set of wave functions that are not manifestly SO(4)−invariant. In 4 we give explicit expressions for the resulting radial functions of the Hydrogen atom in momentum space following our proposal, which have the advantage of being SO(4)−invariant; we also prove the equivalence with the functions of Lombardi-Ogilvie. Finally, in Section 5 we present some conclusions and perspectives for future developments.

sections.heading: 4.4. Comparison between the functions of Podolsky-Pauling and Lombardi-Ogilvie
sections.text:
A comparison between the momentum space wave functions of Podolsky and Pauling, on the one side, with those of Lombardi and Ogilvie, on the other, is in order. For the sake of transparency, we here limit ourselves to compare the corresponding profiles of the momentum distributions, and ignore normalization constants. Also, for illustrative purposes, we select some quantum numbers, for which the expressions look particularly simple. To be specific, below we compare the respective momentum distributions for ` = N − 1. Modulo normalization constants, the Podolsky-Pauling distributions for maximal ` values corresponding to (14), read:

According to (46), the Podolsky-Pauling momentum distribution for the ground
state falls off as (1 + p2/~2β2)−4, a fact experimentally confirmed by [26]. This can be explained by noticing that in the space spanned by the radial Hydrogen atom wave functions and their Fourier transforms to momentum space the following uncertainty relation holds valid:
〈r2〉〈p2〉 ≥ D 2

where D is the dimensionality of the space, D = 3 in our case (see [27])∗. The inequality in (48) encodes the complementary character of r2 and p2, and provides the explanation to the fact that the wave functions of Podolsky and Pauling are the ones appropriate for the description of the p2 expectation values distribution in the Hydrogen atom states. However, if what we want is the distribution of the expectation values of the radial momentum, 〈pr〉, then the Lombardi-Ogilvie wave functions should be more appropriate. Indeed, our conclusion is that the two sets of functions under discussion are complementary to each other. While the ones by Podolsky and Pauling test the distribution of linear momenta with arbitrary orientation, those of Lombardi and Ogilvie would test the distribution of strictly radially aligned momenta, and this could be experimentally confirmed by appropriate radial polarization diffraction experiments, along the lines of [30].
∗ Alternatively, such Heisenberg-like uncertainty relations can also been confirmed and generalized on the basis of information-theoretic methods [28], [29].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text:
We propose a construction of the Hydrogen atom radial wave functions in momentum space from an integral transform which generalizes the case of the free particle momentum representation (see Theorem 1). The corresponding kernel is given by a spherical wave, instead of the traditional plane one, which comes from the consideration of the formal eigenfunctions of the symmetric radial momentum operator (7). This operator, although not self-adjoint, has the feature of satisfying Heisenberg’s commutation rules with the radial coordinate.
The resulting radial wave functions are equivalent to those of Lombardi and Ogilvie
[6, 7], and can be expressed either in terms of finite complex expansions of Gegenbauer functions of the first and second kind (Theorem 2 and Corollary 1), or in terms of (elementary) trigonometric functions (Theorem 3 in Section 4). The first representation reflects the so(2, 1) ∼ su(1, 1) Lie algebra symmetry properties of the momentum wave functions, while the second one shows explicitly properties such as square integrability and SO(4) symmetry, a feature that was absent from the Lombardi-Ogilvie functions.
The total wave functions of the Hydrogen atom in momentum space, if needed,
can be obtained as products of the radial functions presented here with the angular functions either of Lombardi and Ogilvie [7], or with those of Liu, Tang and Xun in [14], giving qualitatively different outcomes. Which is the correct one is a question that must be decided by means of comparison with experimental data.
The wave functions expressed in momentum representation, could be of use in
studying the radial diffraction of hydrogen beams through lattices such as graphene [25], roaming of Hydrogen atoms in the decomposition of organic compounds [31], momentum probabilities for particles in a Coulomb well [32], tunneling [33], [34], and other phenomena, in which Heisenberg’s uncertainty relation between the radial coordinate and the radial momentum is required, among them possibly questions of information entropies [35].
In addition, our approach may also be of interest to the construction of Wigner’s
phase-space functions and their applications, for example, along the lines of [36].
